body: @nunit/core-team Any opinions on which way to go with this? Bear in mind that we have released 3.0 now, so we have backward compatibility to worry about.
@jhamm It's tempting but a bit of a hack, since TestExecutionContext.Current is not really supposed to exist when tests are not being run. I'm concerned that it could have side effects.
I agree that it is an ugly hack. I figured that it was at least worth a mention.
I think we want to stop basing the TestDirectory on the existence of a CurrentTest and just look at the currently executing assembly. We always have one of those. :-)

issue.title: Enable use of TestContext.TestDirectory when tests are being loaded.
issue.body:
Fixes #1241.

I ended up checking for a null CurrentTest and using the calling assembly in that case. This allows TestContext.TestDirectory to work from within a TestCaseSource method, for example.

At the same time, I did some refactoring of TestExecutionContext to make it easier to understand the three different approaches used to hold current context depending on the build platform.
